Why CMP Form Validation?
Clear Module Boundaries

validation-core is a pure Kotlin module with zero Compose dependency. validation-compose provides first-class Compose state integration. Each module is independently publishable with a clean, focused API surface.
Compose-Native Design

No annotation processing, no code generation, no hidden behavior. Validation state lives in your Composable functions via remember APIs, giving you full control and transparency over the validation lifecycle.
Stable by Default
All public Compose-facing models use ImmutableList and ImmutableMap from kotlinx-collections-immutable. This prevents unnecessary recompositions caused by unstable collection types.
Type-Safe Rules
Rule<T> is generic, so you can validate String, Int, or any custom type. Built-in rules cover common patterns, and custom rules take just a few lines to implement.
Multiplatform Support
Write validation logic once, run it on every Compose Multiplatform target. The same rules, validators, and form models work across all platforms without any platform-specific code.

Getting Started
Learn how to add CMP Form Validation to your project and build your first validated form.
~10 min

This guide walks you through installing the library, creating validated fields, connecting them to Material3 text fields, configuring triggers and strategies, building multi-field forms with cross-field validation, and creating custom rules.
1. Add Dependencies
Add the validation modules to your shared module\'s build.gradle.kts. validation-core provides the validation engine; validation-compose adds Compose state integration.
validation-core has no Compose dependency, so you can use it in your data or domain layer.
2. Create a Validated Field
Use rememberValidatedField to create a field with built-in validation rules. This composable remembers validation state across recompositions.
rememberValidatedField returns a ComposeValidatedField that holds the current value, validation result, and touch/blur/submit state. The rules parameter accepts an ImmutableList of Rule<String>.
3. Connect to UI
Bind the validated field to a Material3 OutlinedTextField. The field handles value changes, error state, and error message display.

showErrors is true only when the field should display errors based on the trigger setting. isValid comes from the latest validation result. ValidationSupportingText renders error messages below the field.
4. Choose a Validation Trigger
ValidationTrigger controls when validation runs. Choose the trigger that best fits your UX pattern.
Validates on every keystroke. Provides immediate feedback. Best for short fields like email or username.
Validates when the field loses focus. Less intrusive. Best for forms where real-time feedback is distracting.
Validates only after the first submit() call, then on every subsequent change. Best for traditional form submission flows. This is the default trigger.
5. Choose a Validation Strategy
ValidationStrategy controls how many errors are collected when validation runs.
Runs all rules and collects every error. Use when you want to show all issues at once. This is the default strategy.
Stops at the first failing rule. Use for progressive disclosure of errors, or when later rules depend on earlier ones passing.
6. Build a Multi-Field Form
Combine multiple validated fields into a ValidatedStringForm with cross-field validation rules.

fieldsMatchRule compares two fields by their map keys. When you call form.submit(), it validates all individual fields first, then runs cross-field rules. The return value is true if the entire form is valid.
7. Create Custom Rules
Implement the Rule<T> fun interface to create rules for any validation logic.
Return null if the value passes validation, or a ValidationError with a unique code and descriptive message. The code field enables programmatic error handling.
Integration Styles
Primary (Recommended)
rememberValidatedField + native OutlinedTextField. Full control over UI layout and validation state. Best for most use cases.
Modifier Extension
Modifier.validation(field) adds blur-trigger validation to any text field. Useful when you need minimal changes to existing fields.
Wrapper Component
ValidatedOutlinedTextField combines field, validation, and error display in a single composable. Best for rapid prototyping with less boilerplate.
Use persistentListOf() and persistentMapOf() from kotlinx-collections-immutable for rule and field lists. This prevents unnecessary recompositions.
Cross-field rules run only during form.submit(). They do not trigger on individual field changes.
Use meaningful ErrorCode strings (e.g., "password_too_weak") for programmatic error handling and custom error message rendering.
API Reference
Complete reference for the validation-core and validation-compose modules.
Core Types
Fun interface. Single method: validate(value: T): ValidationError?. Return null for valid, ValidationError for invalid.
Executes a list of rules against a value. Returns ValidationResult. Supports plus operator for combining.
Holds a list of ValidationError instances. Provides isValid property and factory methods valid() and invalid().
Describes a single validation failure. Contains code (unique identifier), defaultMessage, optional path, and metadata map.
Enum: CollectAll (run all rules) or FirstError (stop at first failure).
Object with constants: REQUIRED, MIN_LENGTH, MAX_LENGTH, PATTERN, EMAIL.
Factory function to create a Validator from a variable number of rules. Optional strategy parameter.
Built-in Rules
Fails if the string is blank (or blank after trimming). Default trim = true.
Fails if the string has fewer than min characters.
Fails if the string has more than max characters.
Fails if the string does not match the given Regex pattern.
Fails if the string is not a valid email address format.
Field and Form Types
Core field model. Holds value, validator, trigger, and validation state. Methods: onValueChange, onBlur, validate, submit, reset.
Enum: OnChange, OnBlur, OnSubmitThenChange. Controls when showErrors becomes true.
Multi-field string form. Groups ValidatedField instances with cross-field FormRule list. Methods: submit (returns FormValidationSnapshot), reset.
Fun interface for cross-field validation. validate(values: ImmutableMap<String, String>): ValidationError?
Built-in FormRule that checks two fields have equal values. Commonly used for password confirmation.
Compose API
Creates and remembers a ComposeValidatedField. Overloads accept Validator, vararg rules, or ImmutableList of rules. Optional trigger and strategy parameters.
Creates and remembers a ComposeValidatedStringForm from a map of ComposeValidatedField instances and optional form rules.
Compose-friendly wrapper around ValidatedField. Properties: value, result, touched, blurred, submitted, dirty, showErrors. Methods: onValueChange, onBlur, validate, submit, reset.
Compose-friendly wrapper around ValidatedStringForm. Properties: formErrors. Methods: values, submit (returns Boolean), revalidateCrossField, reset.
Composable that displays validation errors below a field as Material supporting text. Parameters: field, maxErrors (default 1), idleText.
Convenience composable wrapping OutlinedTextField with automatic validation binding. Includes label, placeholder, keyboard options, visual transformation, and error display.
Modifier extension that adds onFocusChanged handling. When validateOnBlur is true (default), calls field.onBlur() when focus is lost.
